choices.text: Grossly it is soft, fleshy, yellow-white tumor with large pale areas of necrosis and extensive hemorrhage
With the use of chemotherapy, the survival rate is close to 100% for cases
Tumor markers like CEA and HCG show high levels

questions.text: 29 years old female complaining of irregular vaginal spotting. She also gave history of miscarriage before 4 months. The histopathology picture is following. Which one from the below is false?
questions.solution:
Answer is Gestational Choriocarcinoma.

Most aggressive form of trophoblastic disease with tumor cells morphologically recapitulating the trophoblast of developing placenta at its previllous stage.

  • Spread: hematogenous spread
  • MC symptom: Vaginal bleeding
  • Extrauterine spread: Lung (60-75%), liver, central nerve system, and
  • Gastrointestinal tract
  • Age : in the reproductive years (mean of 29-31 years)
  • The tumor may arise from any types of prior gestational events:
    • Normal pregnancy,
    • Spontaneous abortion,
    • Complete hydatidiform mole, regardless of its intrauterine or ectopic location (More frequently)(A)
  • Grossly it is a soft, fleshy, yellow-white tumor that usually has large pale areas of necrosis and extensive hemorrhage.
  • Histologically, it consists entirely of proliferating syncytiotrophoblasts and cytotrophoblasts. chorionic villi are absent (As shown in the microscopic image.)
  • When treated by surgery alone, the cure rate was only 40% for tumors apparently restricted to the uterus and less than 20% for those accompanied by metastases. With the use of chemotherapy, the survival rate is close to 100% for cases restricted to the uterus and approximately 83% for patients with metastatic disease.
  • The hCG levels are typically elevated.

Clinical question

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter - 22. page number 1035.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cartilage forming tumor?
questions.solution: Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 26, page number 1187.

choices.text: More frequent above the age of 50 years
Enlarged prostate is nodular, smooth and firm and weighs 2-4 times its normal weight
BPH first develops in peripheral zone

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about benign prostatic hyperplasia?
questions.solution:
Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)

  • BPH first develops in periurethral transition zone, this zone of the gland reacts differently to hormonal stimuli than the outer zones. (Option D)
  • The disease represents a nodular enlargement of the gland caused by hyperplasia of both glandular and stromal components. (Option C)
  • More frequent above the age of 50 years (option A)
  • The enlarged prostate is nodular, smooth and firm and weighs 2-4 times its normal weight i.e. may weigh up to 40-80 gm. (Option B)

Reference:

Textbook of pathology by Harshmohan, 7th edition, section 3, chapter 21, pagenumber 706.

Rosai And Ackerman's Surgical Pathology, 11th Edition, Chapter 26, page number. 1098.

questions.text: A 50 years old female having menorrhagia since past few months. On sonogrpahy, her gynecologist found a unilateral mass in left ovary. Her hysterectomy specimen reveals its firmness and larger size which is gray white in colour. Following microscopic images are from the same ovary. Which of the following diagnoses is correct for this patient?
questions.solution:
Brenner tumor

  • Average age at presentation is approximately 50 years
  • Microscopically, they consist of solid and cystic nests of epithelial cells resembling transitional epithelium (urothelium) surrounded by an abundant stromal component of dense, fibroblastic nature. The epithelial cells have sharply defined outlines; those lining the cysts may be flattened, cuboidal, or columnar. The nuclei of the tumor cells are oval, with a small but distinct nucleolus and longitudinal grooves.

Reference: Rosai And Ackerman's Surgical Pathology, 11th Edition, Chapter 35, page number. 1389.

questions.text: The risk of sarcoma from a developing fibroid uterus is:
questions.solution:
Malignant transformation to leiomyosarcoma is extremely rare.

Uterine leiomyoma (commonly called fibroid) is perhaps the most common tumor in women. They are benign smooth muscle neoplasms that may occur singly, but more often are multiple. The characteristic whorled pattern of smooth muscle bundles is seen microscopically.

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) – Chapter 22, page number 1014.

questions.text: Which of the following immunohistochemical marker is not useful to diagnose prostatic adenocarcinoma?
questions.solution:
• Prostate:
    • Basal cells: p63, 34 beta E12
    • Luminal cells: PSA, prostein, PSMA, NKX3.1, AR
    • Neuroendocrine cells: chromogranin, synaptophysin, CD56
  • Seminal vesicles: AR, PAX8, p63 and 34 beta E12
  • For primary atypical prostatic glands: IHCs reveal atypical prostatic glands negative for p63 and 34 beta E12 (absence of basal cells) and positive for AMACR / p504s, supporting the diagnosis of prostatic adenocarcinoma
  • For disseminated tumor: IHCs reveal tumor cells positive for NKX3.1, PSA and AR, supporting prostatic origin

Reference: Mod Pathol 2018;31:S12, Adv Anat Pathol 2018;25:387

questions.text: Endodermal sinus tumor is characterized by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Yolk sac tumor (also known as endodermal sinus tumor) still ranks as the second most common malignant ovarian tumor of germ cell origin.

It is thought to be derived from malignant germ cells that are differentiating along the extraembryonic yolk sac lineage.

Similar to the normal yolk sac, the tumor cells elaborate α-fetoprotein.

Its characteristic histologic feature is a glomerulus-like structure composed of a central blood vessel enveloped by tumor cells within a space that is also lined by tumor cells (Schiller-Duval body)


Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 22, page number 1025.

questions.text: Endometrial metaplasia include all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
Types of endometrial metaplasia:-

Mnemonic- PCOS May Arise in  Hairy & Symptomatic girl

  • Papillary syncytial metaplasia
  • Ciliated cell (tubal) metaplasia
  • Oncocytic (eosinophilic) metaplasia
  • Squamous metaplasia
  • Mucinous metaplasia
  • Hobnail and clear cell metaplasia
  • Arias stella reaction
  • Stromal metaplasia

Reference: Rosai And Ackerman's Surgical Pathology, 11th Edition, Chapter 33, page number. 1299, 1300.

questions.text: A 19 years old girl has yet to have her menstrual period, and she is embarrassed about hair growth on her upper lip. Lab tests reveals FSH of 7.2 IU/L, LH of 6.2 IU/L, and 17-hydroxyprogesterone of 7.4 ng/mL. From the following, which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• 3 causes of hirsutism in this clinical scenario are
    • Polycystic ovarian syndrome
    • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia
    • Cushing's disease
  • In congenital adrenal hyperplasia and polycystic ovarian syndrome, the 17-hydroxyprogesterone concentration can be elevated. (Option D)
  • In polycystic ovarian syndrome, the LH will be elevated, and the LH:FSH ratio would be around 2.5 (option A).
  • Cushing's disease would not be associated with changes in LH or FSH (option B).
  • Addison's disease is not associated with amenorrhea (option C).

Reference: Textbook of pathology by Harshmohan, 7th edition, section 3, chapter 25, page number:788.

questions.text: A 42 years old male presents with painless enlargement of testis. Serum HCG levels are high for this patient. From the following, all are the possibilities can be excepted, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Seminoma is the most common germ cell tumor of the testis.

  • Serum hCG levels, elaborated by syncytiotrophoblasts, are elevated in about 15% of cases, but these elevations are not as high as those seen in choriocarcinoma.
  • The tumor is highly radiosensitive and often curable, even when metastatic.

Embryonal carcinoma is highly pleomorphic and is much less responsive to therapy than seminoma. It shows high AFP and hcg levels.

Yolk sac tumor is the most common tumor of the testis during infancy and early childhood and is usually accompanied by an increase in serum α-fetoprotein.

hCG is synthesised by placental syncytiotrophoblast such as in various non-seminomatous germ cell tumours of the testis (e.g. in choriocarcinoma, yolk sac tumour and embryonal carcinoma). However, ectopic hCG production may occur in a variety of nontesticular non-germ cell tumours as well.

Reference: Textbook of pathology by Harshmohan, 7th edition, section 3, chapter 21, page number 697

questions.text: A 24 years old man presents with acute and chronic inflammation of his glans penis. All of the following, which is the most likely complication of chronic balanitis in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Balanitis usually extends from the glans of the penis to the foreskin and is called balanoposthitis.
  • Most often, it is caused by bacterial infection, but in immunosuppressed persons and in diabetics, it can also be caused by fungi.
  • Typically, balanitis is a consequence of poor hygiene in uncircumcised men.
  • Significant complications of chronic balanoposthitis are stricture of the meatus, phimosis, and paraphimosis.
  • The orifice of the prepuce may be too narrow to allow retraction over the glans penis, in which case the condition is referred to as phimosis.
  • If the narrow prepuce is forcefully retracted, it may strangulate the glans and impede the outflow of venous blood, a disorder known as paraphimosis.

Reference: Textbook of pathology by Harshmohan, 7th edition, section 3, chapter 21, page number 702

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis according to the gross and microscopic images of right oophorectomy measuring 11x8x5 cms.
questions.solution:
• Ovarian mucinous tumors have been divided into
    • Benign (mucinous cystadenoma)
    • Borderline
    • Malignant (mucinous carcinoma) most mucinous tumors are benign or borderline.
  • Grossly, they tend to grow larger than the serous types and are partially or completely cystic, often multiloculated and have a smooth surface. A fluid to viscous material of mucoid nature is present in the lumen
  • Microscopically, The epithelium is referred to as intestinal (in contrast to the endocervical-like epithelium and is characterized by an epithelial lining with a "picket fence" appearance, goblet cells, Paneth cells, endocrine cells, the secretion of gastrointestinal or pancreatobiliary type mucin.

Reference: Rosai And Ackerman's Surgical Pathology, 11th Edition, Chapter 35, page number 1383.

questions.text: A mother complains of enlarged testis of his 2 years old male baby to a surgeon. The orchidectomy specimen have following microscopic features. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Teratomas have a variety of tissues imparts a heterogeneous appearance, with solid, sometimes cartilaginous, and cystic areas.

Mature teratoma is composed of disorderly mixture of a variety of welldifferentiated structures such as cartilage, smooth muscle, intestinal and respiratory epithelium, mucus glands, cysts lined by squamous and transitional epithelium, neural tissue, fat and bone.

This type of mature or differentiated teratoma is the most common, seen more frequently in infants and children and has favourable prognosis.

Reference: Textbook of pathology by Harshmohan, 7th edition, section 3, chapter 21, page number 699.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of Addison's disease in India?
questions.solution:
Most common causes of Addison's disease

  • In developing countries - Tuberculous adrenalitis
  • In developed countries - Autoimmune adrenalitis

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 24, page number 1123.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false for paget's disease of bone?
questions.solution:
• Paget's disease (Osteitis Deformans) is a chronic bone disorder characterized by abnormal bone growth and remodeling.
    • An initial osteolytic stage
    • A mixed osteoclastic-osteoblastic stage
    • A burned-out quiescent osteosclerotic stage in which osteoblast activity predominates.
  • Microscopy - Its hallmark is a mosaic pattern of lamellar bone that develops in the sclerotic phase. This jigsaw puzzle-like appearance is produced by unusually prominent cement lines, which join haphazardly oriented units of lamellar bone. (Option B)
  • The axial skeleton or proximal femur is involved in up to 80% of cases.
  • Physical examination :-
    • Localized warmth and pain
    • Abnormal gait or balance impairment
    • Assymetrical bony deformities - Enlargement of the craniofacial skeleton may produce leontiasis ossea (lion face) (option C) and heavy cranium
  • The most dreaded complication of Paget disease is sarcoma, which occurs in less than 1% of all individuals with Paget disease, and in 5% to 10% of those with severe polyostotic disease. The sarcomas, usually osteosarcoma or fibrosarcoma, arise in Paget lesions in the long bones, pelvis, skull, and spine. (Option A)
  • Treatment - Bisphosphonates

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 26, page number 1183, 1184.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of Multiple endocrine neoplasia, type 2A (MEN-2A)?
questions.solution: Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 24, page number 1127.

questions.text: A 41-year-old female has a brown macule on her right arm. The biopsy of this lesion shows proliferation of bland nevus cells in the dermis. Rare mitotic activity is found. Of the following, what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is intradermal nevus.

  • Nuclei of nevus cells are uniform and rounded in contour, contain inconspicuous nucleoli, and show little or no mitotic activity. Bland cells with absence of cytological atypia and no mitotic activity rule out malignant melanoma and dysplastic nevus. Cytologic atypia takes the form of nuclear enlargement; irregular, often angulated, nuclear contours; and hyperchromasia.
  • In intradermal nevi, the nevus cells are confined to the dermis (B). Also intradermal nevus is not a greatest risk factor for the development of malignant melanoma.
  • Dysplastic nevi are direct precursors of melanoma. Microscopically, it involves both the epidermis and the dermis and exhibit architectural and cytologic atypia. (A)
  • Junctional nevus exhibits the presence of proliferating cells at the basal portion of epidermis which Consist of aggregates or nests of round cells that grow along the dermoepidermal junction(C)
  • In compound nevus, these cells are present at both the site, the basal portion of the epidermis, and within the dermis. (D)

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) – Chapter 25, page number 1136

choices.text: Deposition of amyloid is a characteristic feature of many insulinomas
Gastrinomas are locally invasive or have already metastasized at the time of diagnosis
Glucagonoma shows symptoms of watery diarrhea with hypokalemia and achlorhydria
Gastrinomas in patients with MEN-I mostly occur in the dudodenum

questions.text: Which one of the following is false regarding the islet cell tumor of the pancreas?
questions.solution:
Functioning tumors are often pancreatic and discovered earlier due to symptoms. Non functioning tumors are diagnosed later (with metastasis) or incidentally.


Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 24, page number 1113,1114.

questions.text: A 20 years old woman came to emergency room having seizure, who is found to have profound hypoglycemia. Determination of which of the following would aid in differentiating exogenous hyperinsulinemia from endogenous hyperinsulinemia?
questions.solution:
• C-peptide is a valuable marker for distinguishing endogenous insulin production from exogenous insulin administration. It's produced along with insulin but is removed during the purification process of commercial insulin preparations.
  • Therefore, elevated levels of C-peptide indicate endogenous insulin production, as seen in conditions like insulinoma, whereas exogenous insulin administration does not lead to an increase in circulating C-peptide levels.
  • Reference range of C-peptide: 0.78-1.89 ng/ml
  • Serum c-peptide levels are very low to absent in type 1 diabetes melitus, and normal to increased in type 2 diabetes melitus.

Reference:

Textbook of pathology by Harshmohan, 7th edition, section 3, chapter 25, page number 810.

Essentials of clinical pathology, 1st edition, chapter 3, page number, 42,51.

questions.text: The parents of a 3-week-old girl complain that their baby is apathetic and sluggish. On physical examination, the child's abdomen is large and exhibits an umbilical hernia. The skin is pale and cold, and the temperature is 35°C (95°F). Which of the following would be more likely the cause for the signs and symptoms of this child?
questions.solution:
Thyroid agenesis (cretinism)

The provided text outlines the features and consequences of congenital hypothyroidism, commonly referred to as cretinism.

It emphasizes the importance of early detection and treatment to prevent severe neurological and physical impairments in affected individuals.

A cretin is a child with severe hypothyroidism present at birth or developing within first two years of postnatal life. This is the period when brain development is taking place; in the absence of treatment the child is both physically and mentally retarded.

High levels of TSH and fall in T3 and T4 levels.

Clinical signs:

  • Slow to thrive
  • Poor feeding
  • Constipation
  • Dry scaly skin
  • Hoarse cry
  • Bradycardia
  • Impaired skeletal growth and consequent dwarfism
  • Round face
  • Narrow forehead
  • Widely set eyes
  • Flat and broad nose
  • Big protuberant tongue
  • Protuberant abdomen.
  • Neurological features such as deafmutism, spasticity and mental deficiency

Reference: Textbook of pathology by Harshmohan, 7th edition, section 3, chapter 25, page number.794.

choices.text: It is greater than 90% of pancreatic cancers arise from pancreatic intraepethial neoplasia (panIN)
Distant metastases are principally to the liver and lungs
Most common pancreatic cancer arises in the body of pancreas
KRAS (chromosome 12p) is the most frequently altered oncogene

questions.text: All of the following are true about pancreatic carcinoma, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Invasive pancreatic cancers arise from noninvasive precursor lesions referred to as pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN) . These lesions develop in small ducts and are often microscopic, although some, such as the two variants of cystic mucinous neoplasms described above, can be detected macroscopically.
  • Overall, it is thought that greater than 90% of pancreatic cancers arise from PanIN (option A)
  • KRAS (chromosome 12p) is the most frequently altered oncogene in pancreatic cancer, with activating point mutations present in greater than 90% of cases. (Option D)
  • 60% of pancreatic cancers arise in the head, 15% in the body, and 5% in the tail; in 20% of cases the entire pancreas is involved.(option C)
  • Distant metastases are principally to the liver and lungs.(option B)

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) – Chapter 24, page number. 890-893.

choices.text: This condition may appear in both forms, autosomal dominant and autosomal recessive

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about marble bone disease?
questions.solution:
Osteopetrosis, also called marble bone disease,

  • It is caused by a hereditary defect in osteoclast function. (Option A)
  • The condition may appear in 2 forms: autosomal recessive (malignant infantile form) and autosomal dominant (benign adult form). (Option B)
  • Failure of normal osteoclast function of bone resorption coupled with continued bone formation and endochondral ossification results in net overgrowth of calcified dense bone (too much bone) (option D)
  • More susceptible to get fractures.
  • Besides the skeletal abnormalities, the infantile malignant form is characterised by effects of marrow obliteration such as anaemia, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia, hepatosplenomegaly with extramedullary haematopoiesis, hydrocephalus and neurologic involvement with consequent deafness, optic atrophy and blindness.
  • Metabolically, hypocalcaemia occurs due to defective osteoclast function. (Option C)
  • Microscopy - the number of osteoclasts is increased which have dysplastic, bizarre and irregular nuclei and are dysfunctional.

Reference: Textbook of pathology by Harshmohan, 7th edition, chapter 26, page number.825.

questions.text: A 30 years old primigravida develops gestational diabetes and remains hyperglycemic during the whole remainder of her pregnancy. Which of the following abnormalities in her newborn child is likely related to this condition?
questions.solution:
Gestational diabetes

  • The most common effect of maternal diabetes mellitus and hyperglycemia on the child is increased birth weight.
  • Poorly controlled diabetes that arises later in pregnancy, regardless of prior history, can lead to excessive birth weight in the newborn (macrosomia) and may have long-term sequelae for the child later in life, including an increased risk of obesity and diabetes.
  • Another complication is hyaline membrane disease.

Cretinism results from deficiency of thyroid hormone during fetal development and during ppostnata life.

Ambiguous genitalia can occur in any of the adrenogenital syndromes.

Sheehan syndrome occurs in the mother and has no relationship to diabetes.

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) – Chapter 24, page number 1105.

questions.text: A 35 years old female complains of amenorrhea, galactorrhea and visual field defects since last many months. MRI reveals a hypophyseal mass imaging on the optic chiasm. The electron microscopy findings show the tumor cells contain abundant Granular endoplasmic reticulum and small numbers of electron-dense secretory granules. What could be the possible diagnosis here from the following?
questions.solution:
• Prolactinoma /Lactotroph adenoma (option B)
    • The findings described are associated with prolactinoma (The most common hormone-secreting tumor of the pituitary).
    • Hyperprolactinemia results in amenorrhea and galactorrhea. The tumor is generally small; however, about 10% are large enough to impinge on adjacent structures, and bitemporal hemianopsia from pressure on the optic chiasm is common.
  • Somatotropic adenoma (an older name is acidophilic adenoma) secretes growth hormone (GH), causing acromegaly or gigantism. (Option A)
  • Corticotropic adenoma secretes ACTH, causing Cushing syndrome of pituitary origin (Cushing disease). (Option D)
  • Craniopharyngioma is a nonendocrine tumor of Rathke pouch origin that can be locally destructive, indirectly causing panhypopituitarism. (Option C)

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 24, page number 1070, 1071.

questions.text: This subcutaneous cyst, found in the right orbital region, is a/an:
questions.solution: Reference: Weedon's Skin Pathology (5th edition) – Chapter 17, page number 544.
